Noah Campbell wrote:
>  
> 
> What nice about HATEOAS is that you can inject commentary, system 
> status, whatever you like if you're using HTML.  This additional 
> information helps those in meatspace[1] understand and interact with 
> your resources.  I've used javascript to provide interactivity when a 
> representation is sent to the client.  The sweet part is that the agents 
> are processing the link/rel tags and never care about the javascript or 
> surrounding html.  Microformats help here as well.  Since these were 
> specific to the application, I didn't have to bother with defining new 
> media types.
> 
> 
> I've been asked/challenged on what is the WSDL equivalent for RESTful 
> architecture is and my answer included the above plus the need for the 
> agent to query.  Querying the document for links/rel tags allows for 
> arbitrary content to be included which I believe is a good thing and 
> promoted the pattern above.  WADL/WSDL is much too brittle for my taste 
> because these techniques rely on ordinal positions or link templates to 
> navigate the hypermedia.  I've blogged about the need to query here [2].
> 

The only thing I see something like WADL is useful for is testing via 
tools/ide.  Then again, you might be able to get there just as easily 
from what you describe above.

Bill
